channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Afghanistan: Evacuation will continue despite Kabul attack, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson calls the attack "barbaric" and "despicable", and promises to continue UK operations.

item.title: Kabul airport attack: What do we know?
item.description: The bombings came hours after warnings to citizens to stay away from the airport, due to an imminent threat.

item.title: Afghanistan: Charity worker Pen Farthing caught up in Kabul attack
item.description: The ex-Royal Marine, who was near to the airport explosions, describes how "all hell broke loose".

item.title: Covid travel: Seven locations moved to Covid travel green list
item.description: Canada and Denmark go on the green list while Thailand and Montenegro move to the UK red list.

item.title: Lisa Shaw: Presenter's death due to complications of Covid vaccine
item.description: Lisa Shaw developed headaches shortly after being vaccinated against Covid-19, an inquest hears.

item.title: Benjamin Mendy: Manchester City footballer charged with rape
item.description: Defender Benjamin Mendy is charged with four counts of rape and one count of sexual assault.

item.title: Food firm in 'drastic' action amid driver shortage
item.description: Wholesaler Country Range says it is buying smaller vans to get round the lack of HGV drivers.

item.title: Champions League draw: Manchester City to face PSG and Chelsea will meet Juventus
item.description: Premier League champions Manchester City will face Lionel Messi's new club Paris St-Germain in the Champions League group stage.

item.title: BA in talks over short-haul Gatwick flights
item.description: The airline confirmed it was talking with unions on plans to create a short-haul flight operation.

item.title: US judge reprimands Trump election fraud lawyers
item.description: A US district judge accuses Sidney Powell and others of trying to undermine faith in democracy.

item.title: NHS blood test tube shortage set to worsen
item.description: NHS England admits supplies of the tubes will become "even more constrained over the coming weeks".

item.title: Mass brawl erupts in Armenian parliament: Third violent bout in just two days
item.description: Security personnel were called in to remove several members after violence erupted on the parliament floor.

item.title: The Papers: 'Bloodbath at Kabul airport'
item.description: Reports of the twin bomb attacks in Afghanistan's capital feature across the front pages, alongside some dramatic photographs.

item.title: Eating disorders: Charity reports rise in calls about binge eating
item.description: The charity Beat reports a surge in the number of people requesting help for Binge Eating Disorder.

item.title: Taylor Wessing Prize 2021: Shortlisted photographers revealed
item.description: The three shortlisted photographers for the prestigious Taylor Wessing Prize have been revealed.

item.title: Nah he tweakin: What it means and why it's all over our timelines
item.description: A row on the use of blood in celebrity-endorsed products has made those three words viral.

item.title: Abba: Band teases major announcement ahead of new music
item.description: The band, who have not released new music for 39 years, reveal a new project called Abba Voyage.

item.title: Tortoise eating bird caught on camera by conservationist
item.description: It is believed to be the first time this behaviour of giant tortoises has been documented.

item.title: Custard to be reinstated in Aberdeenshire after school petition
item.description: Aberdeenshire pupils took action to reinstate their favourite puddings, described as the "best in the world".

item.title: Australian farmer draws heart with sheep in tribute to aunt
item.description: The Australian man was unable to attend his aunt's funeral because of Covid travel restrictions.

item.title: Nile Rodgers offers career tips to young musicians
item.description: After months of staying at home, the music legend taught young Londoners the benefit of collaboration.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics 2020: Kgothatso Montjane, South Africa's wheelchair tennis hope
item.description: South Africa's wheelchair tennis star Kgothatso Montjane is aiming for a medal at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: 'My husband refused a divorce for nine years'
item.description: Under orthodox Jewish law, a husband must give his wife a document to allow the marriage to end.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Britain's Ali Jawad says he has 'been in self-isolation for three years'
item.description: British powerlifter Ali Jawad says he has effectively self-isolated for three years to make it to the Paralympics.

item.title: Why rent control isn’t working in Sweden
item.description: Young people are struggling to afford city living, and even the Swedes can't crack the problem.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: How serious is the shortage of lorry drivers?
item.description: The industry says there's a shortage of 100,000 drivers but why is that and what is the likely impact?

item.title: Ted Dexter: Former England and Sussex captain dies aged 86 - obituary
item.description: "Lord Ted" Dexter was an attacking batsman who captained Sussex and England - though success eluded him as chairman of selectors.

item.title: The real victims of mass crypto-hacks that keep happening
item.description: Millions in Bitcoin and other digital coins are being stolen by hackers with victims left in limbo.

item.title: England v India: Joe Root's stunning year and the records he could break
item.description: Another Test, another brilliant Joe Root century. Just how good is the England captain - and which records are under threat?

item.title: Kane scores twice as Tottenham go through in Europe
item.description: Harry Kane scores twice on his return to the Tottenham starting line-up as Spurs overturned a first-leg deficit against Pacos de Ferreira to reach the Europa Conference League group stage.

item.title: Fraser-Pryce runs third fastest women's 100m time in history to beat Thompson-Herah
item.description: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce runs the third fastest time in women's 100m history to beat Elaine Thompson-Herah at the Diamond League in Lausanne.

item.title: Another Root century punishes India as England amass huge lead
item.description: England captain Joe Root continues his stellar form with yet another magnificent century to flatten India on day two of the third Test at Headingley.

item.title: Celtic survive testing night to edge past AZ in Europa League
item.description: Celtic survive a torrid night in the Netherlands to edge past AZ Alkmaar on aggregate and reach the Europa League groups for the fourth season running.

item.title: US Open: Emma Raducanu one win away from qualifying for Grand Slam
item.description: Britain's Emma Raducanu is one win away from the US Open main draw after beating Mariam Bolkvadze in the second round of qualifying.

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo to Man City: Could Juventus forward end up at Etihad Stadium?
item.description: BBC Radio 5 Live's Euro Leagues team discuss Cristiano Ronaldo's potential move to Manchester City.

item.title: Kabul arrivals in the UK: 'The happiest moment of my life'
item.description: UK troops are evacuating British nationals and eligible Afghans. Here are some of their stories.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Who are Isis-K?
item.description: The jihadist group - set up in 2015 - is blamed for some of the worst atrocities in recent years.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'The pain of watching my country burn from afar'
item.description: Hundreds of Afghan have taken refuge in India but they are worried about their families back home.

item.title: Afghanistan chaos: The British families in limbo
item.description: The stories of Britons stuck in Kabul, families in limbo and Afghans starting new lives in the UK.

item.title: Afghanistan: The Sandhurst sisterhood trying to save Afghans
item.description: Desperate Afghans have been messaging British veterans they used to work with asking for help.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Aryana Sayeed: Afghanistan returns to miserable time for women
item.description: Afghan singer Aryana Sayeed on fleeing the country and her concerns for those who remain.

item.title: What is Sharia law? What does it mean for women in Afghanistan?
item.description: The Taliban say they will govern Afghanistan according to Sharia, or Islamic law

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Lee Pearson wins 12th gold as GB enjoy cycling and swimming success
item.description: Lee Pearson wins his 12th gold medal as Great Britain enjoy a successful day two at the Tokyo Paralympics

item.title: GB's Kearney wins 100m freestyle gold in record time
item.description: Watch ParalympicsGB's Tully Kearney win gold in the women's S5 100m freestyle final in Tokyo, breaking her own world record.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Jaco van Gass - from injury in Afghanistan to Paralympic champion
item.description: Twelve years ago, Jaco van Gass was fighting for his life after being injured in Afghanistan. Now he's a Paralympic champion.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics medal table - which country has won most golds?
item.description: Which country is leading the medal table for the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How are Great Britain getting on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: The lowdown on being disabled in Japan
item.description: From moon riders to job quotas, three residents give the lowdown on being disabled in Japan.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Tanni Grey-Thompson column: 'Tokyo can still be a step forward for Paralympics'
item.description: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson believes the Tokyo Paralympics can still take the movement to another level.

item.title: Suzanna Hext: Paralympic swimmer prepares for Tokyo 2020 having watched London 2012 from hospital
item.description: From watching London 2012 from her hospital bed to swimming for ParalympicsGB at Tokyo 2020 - Suzanna Hext's Paralympic journey.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight Great Britain athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the 'Weirwolf' to a potential swimming star, who are some of the Great Britain athletes hoping to shine at the Tokyo Paralympics?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Ellie Simmonds and John Stubbs to carry GB flag
item.description: Swimmer Ellie Simmonds and archer John Stubbs will carry the GB flag at Tuesday's Tokyo Paralympics opening ceremony.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight global athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the Blade Jumper to the dancing star and the Tik Tok influencer, meet some of the global athletes hoping to make an impact at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.
